article_title: Countdown to coverage: UMHS offers free help with enrolling in private plans and Michigan Medicaid plans
article_text:
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — If you live in Michigan and you don’t have health insurance, you don’t have a moment to lose.

Next Monday, March 31, is essentially the last day when you can enroll in a private insurance plan for yourself or your family -- unless something big happens in your life later this year. Depending on your income, you can get a break on the cost of insurance.

For low-income people, next Tuesday, April 1, is the first day to enroll in a brand-new public plan – called the Healthy Michigan plan. It’s a Medicaid program, but it’s open to many people who couldn’t get Medicaid before now. Signups will continue all year.

During this crunch time for insurance enrollment, the University of Michigan Health System will offer free help to anyone who needs it – whether or not they get their health care at U-M hospitals or health centers.

A trained team of UMHS counselors has been helping people understand their options under the Affordable Care Act since last September. They can help anyone figure out what plans they and their families might be eligible for, and actually enroll.

Besides private plans sold on the national health insurance Marketplace, and the new Healthy Michigan plans, the counselors can help Michiganders enroll in other programs that they might be eligible for – including county plans for people who don’t qualify for other types of insurance.

Coming to U-M for care once you have coverage

U-M doctors and teams have already treated many patients who have bought private health insurance on the national Marketplace (including www.healthcare.gov) since last fall. UMHS accepts many of the private plans directly, and members of other plans may be able to receive care at U-M with a referral from their doctor.

Once Healthy Michigan plans begin offering coverage on April 1, UMHS will accept many of them for all types of care, and one plan for specialty care only. For people enrolled in other Healthy Michigan plans, it may still be possible to come to UMHS for specialty care if no hospital in their plan’s network has the services they need.

For the full lists of plans UMHS accepts, see http://www.uofmhealth.org/ACAplans.

Any patient, visitor or community member can get help in enrolling in a private or Medicaid plan from UMHS Patient Financial Counselors by calling (877) 326-9155 from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday-Friday or emailing PFC-Counselors@med.umich.edu. Walk-in help is available at several locations around the U-M medical campus and health centers.

The UMHS Regional Alliance for Healthy Schools (RAHS) also has several trained counselors available to offer by-appointment help. Call 734-998-5795 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday-Friday, or email UMHS-RAHS@umich.edu .

U-M students trained in talking with the public will continue to assist with outreach to people who have sought free care from U-M providers through the Hope Clinic and Student Run Free Clinic, as well as others. This outreach effort was organized through the Washtenaw Health Initiative, which is partly supported by UMHS. Those clinics and others will continue to care for uninsured people, including those not eligible for any Affordable Care Act plans.

More about Healthy Michigan Medicaid coverage

Starting April 1, Michiganders between the ages of 19 and 64 can sign up for Healthy Michigan if their income is less than 133 percent of the federal poverty level -- about $15,000 for a single person and $34,000 for a family of four. Eligibility is based on “modified adjusted gross income” – which for most people will be the same as what they report on their taxes.

Unlike traditional Medicaid, Healthy Michigan is open to anyone whose income falls under the 133 percent figure – including childless adults – although currently pregnant women should apply for other programs specifically for them. Even people who were turned down for Medicaid in the past should apply if their income is low enough.

People in Healthy Michigan plans whose incomes are more than 100 percent of the poverty level will need to set up a healthcare savings account to help them pay for their costs in future. Just as in regular Medicaid, there will be small co-pays for services – including for emergency department visits for non-emergencies, and for non-emergency hospital admissions

Members of Healthy Michigan plans will also have to complete a health assessment form, with the help of a health provider who they should see within the first few months of getting coverage.

In addition to Healthy Michigan plans, the state offers other insurance coverage programs. Many people don’t know that they or their children are eligible for these, but U-M counselors can assist.

Key Affordable Care Act dates and deadlines:

March 31 – Open enrollment ends for private individual/family plans on the Marketplace; coverage will begin May 1. People who sign up between March 15 and 31 will have to file an exemption when they file their federal taxes next year. Note: On March 25, the federal government announced that people who had started an application by March 31 but had been unable to complete it will be able to do so by mid-April.

April 1 - Enrollment in Healthy Michigan (expanded Medicaid) plans begins. Coverage begins April 1, no matter when someone enrolls.

March 31 is also the deadline for all Americans to meet the requirement of having health insurance for all or most of 2014. Most people who don’t meet this deadline will have to pay a fee of $95 or 1 percent of their income, on top of their income taxes, in early 2015.

All year – Someone who has a qualifying life event (such as the birth of a baby or marriage) can enroll in a Marketplace plan, or change plans, even when open enrollment is closed.

November 15 – Open enrollment begins for private plans for calendar year 2015

For more information about UMHS and the Affordable Care Act, visit http://www.uofmhealth.org/newoptions
